Abortion isn't wrong. Late term abortions, when the fetus is autonomous and in no need of sustaining itself off of the mother's body is wrong. It's wrong past that point when the mother's health isn't threatened.
 
 But Abortion isn't wrong beforehand. Prior to late term abortions, your common housecat has more of a right to life than a Human fetus and embryo.
 
 The above do not have the rational autonomy, the IQ to be considered anything special. You do not have rights soley because you are a specific species. Your rights come from reason and your autonomy, rationality, degree of sapience/sentience.
 
 Your father doesn't sex your mom up and boom, conception: you have autonomy and rationality. That's not the way it goes.

 Imagine yourself, a baby cow. You are just sitting there feeling your feelings, ,living fine when all of the sudden BAM, you're shot in the face with a bolt, killing you. Then you get served on a plate and are yummy in someone's tummy.

Imagine yourself, a baby cow. You are just sitting there feeling your feelings, ,living fine when all of the sudden BAM, you're shot in the face with a bolt, killing you. Then you get served on a plate and are yummy in someone's tummy.
 
 There's no difference. A baby cow has more autonomy than a fetus, and it probably has a higher IQ.
 
 Largely, this is an attemped appeal to emotion without looking rationally, logically at the state of the fetus. There are higher concerns rather than mere pain/pleasure. YOu want to limit how much is necessary,b ut there are other Utilitarian concerns and other moral concerns at work.

 wow... this is a rather callous analogy. the fact is, along with the recognition of human rights, there is an emotional attachment and sentimental value that we give to people and not cows. i agree that not all people regard unborn babies as valuable assest to society, but most dont devaluate them to the level of a domesticated animal bred for food. there is a very big difference to many many people, even those that support the right to abortion.
 
 i think this "devaluation" of human life is what upsets most pro-life activists. i'm not saying that you personally dont value others, but your argument is an example of what pro-lifers go ballistic over. the question of human value, whether intrinsic or relative, must be addressed in these types of debates. i dont agree that we need to rescue and preserve every life in the world, but at the same time i strongly disagree with the view that human lives are no more valuable that that of animals (again, i'm not saying that this is your personal view, just the argument you offered)
Another opinion

now lets say thats you as a fetus what are your feelings. sitting there living fine when all of a sudden a pair of large metal objects come in and kill you. Then what.

 That question is only relevant if you, as a fetus, actually CAN feel. First trimester fetus's cannot, late term fetus's can. I have the same empathy toward fetus's that can actually feel and have emotions and believe that, because of our concept of the right to life of PEOPLE (human lives with minds), would outlaw abortion in the third trimester.
 
 However, your arguement is irrelevant to first trimester abortions, which make up about 88% of the total.

One point that is being avoided here is that any baby(fetus) has the right to life, no matter what stage of development. Why does the fact that they can feelthe pain, as apposed to not, change ones thoughts on abortion? They are still killed and never get the chance to live in this world. Ask yourselves, what if i were aborted? What if Einstein, Columbus, Newton, Martin L. King, etc. were? Then it is a shame, for ANY life to be taken.
Another opinion

One point that is being avoided here is that any baby(fetus) has the right to life, no matter what stage of development. Why does the fact that they can feelthe pain, as apposed to not, change ones thoughts on abortion? They are still killed and never get the chance to live in this world. 
 The big difference is what they are **at the moment** when they are being aborted. What they are is much more important than what they will be. If they cannot feel, do not have any thoughts, emotions, not even a sense of self, then how in the world can you think of them as a person at that point in time? Yes, if left alone, they probably will develop into a person and the life of such a potential person should not be taken lightly. However, all of the rights, freedoms, and protections which our country, and most free civilizations, were founded on are for PEOPLE, not for potential people. It is an inherent assumption under all of the rights and laws. The rights of an actual person should always take precedence over that of a life that is not a person.
 
 Also, I know that this type of arguement is controversial, but if you take your idea that all potential life should have an overriding right to be protected, then one could argue that using contraception (either chemical or natural) is depriving a potential person of its right to life.
 
 
Ask yourselves, what if i were aborted? What if Einstein, Columbus, Newton, Martin L. King, etc. were? Then it is a shame, for ANY life to be taken.
 If I had been developed enough to feel pain, emotions, etc. , then it would have been a terrible experience but, of course, this would only be valid in very late stages of pregnancy. If I had been aborted in earlier stages, then I never would have known it - just like all the billions of potential people who had never been born due to early miscarriages, or even contraception. As for a potential life becoming a Columbus, Newton, etc., it just as easily could have become a Hitler, Stalin, or serial killer.

One point that is being avoided here is that any baby(fetus) has the right to life, no matter what stage of development. Why does the fact that they can feelthe pain, as apposed to not, change ones thoughts on abortion? They are still killed and never get the chance to live in this world.

 
 A lot of pro-lifers like to think that the Fetus is on the same level as a born, or almost-to-be-born, Human being, when it isn't. A fetus is nothing more than a pre-born human that, in many instances, cannot feel pain/pleasure, therefore prior to that point it does not and will never factor into a Utilitarian calculation. Even later in pregnancy, the actual line of demarcation after which they can feel pain/pleasure is blurry, and it is difficult to tell whether or not they are feeling it or just responding to the external stimuli.
 
 Furthermore, there is zero reason to treat a FEtus as a moral person as you would an adult, a child, or even a newborn baby for reasons other than pure pain/pleasure experience capability. Y ou have to look at the level of Rational Autonomy of the creature.
 
 The fact that something is alive does not give it a right to life. There are no Rights intrinsically. Humans and other animals kill other livign creatuers all the time, and Humans can easily rationalize this. It's not immoral to kill to eat or to kill to survive. Life itself is intrinsicially netural in value. Many pro-lifers like to espouse a lot of relgious motiviation behind their claims of value to human life---the sanctity of life.
 
 All things being equal, this really doesn't exist. THere is nothing intrinsically important about Human life at all stages. It depends on the stage. At many stages during the pregnancy, the Fetus is a non-autonomous, low IQ creature that doesn't have a developed sense of self-awareness, or sentience. It also does not posses sapience.
 
 These things make creatuers valuable moral persons. A fetus has less sentience and a lower level of autonomy and ratinoality that that of a Cat. As a fetus, both the Human Fetus and the Cat Fetus are relatively equal--both are unautonomous, unfeeling, and non-sentient/sapient. There is no reason, other than pure speciest bias ,which isn't a legitimate moral factor, that separates choice between the two.
 
 The fact that we kill fully grown cats and think nothing of the sort as we do with a Human fetus is, quite frankly, silly. There's no objectivity behind it. Humans are merely another animal, and we aren't even a "higher" grade animal, since there is no such hierarchy according to evolution.
 
 Even after birth, the fetus isn't at a significant level of self-awareness of being aware: sapient.
dutch

 Let's examine this post.
 
 No one has a right to anything. Rights are acquired and protected through force. You don't have a right to have any rights. Rights must be taken, they are not inherent.
